currentDoc:
Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of femalstudents.

Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junio

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I awould carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the g

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their fampeers.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with e

Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, so even middl

Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students ther

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to tak

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it poss

Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now, with a higher proportion of low income students, the situation is different?

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain wh

Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are studen

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by ?

Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by an increasingly?

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increa?

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel ?

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young wom

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed aboof their periods?

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons. Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and les

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well a

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well as with many others, the problem is not that the schools are failing to provide pads and tampons, but that the students are failing to take responsibility for themselves

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well as with many others, the problem is not that the schools are failing to provide pads and tampons, but that the students are failing to take responsibility for themselves, because they are les

Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well as with many others, the problem is not that the schools are failing to provide pads and tampons, but that the students are failing to take responsibility for themselves, because they are less well informed and r

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well as with many others, the problem is not that the schools are failing to provide pads and tampons, but that the students are failing to take responsibility for themselves, because they are less well informed and responsible than the

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well as with many others, the problem is not that the schools are failing to provide pads and tampons, but that the students are failing to take responsibility for themselves, because they are less well informed and responsible than they should be. Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well as with many others, the problem is not that the schools are failing to provide pads and tampons, but that the students are failing to take responsibility for themselves, because they are less well informed and responsible than they should be. This is not the schools' fault, it is the faul

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well as with many others, the problem is not that the schools are failing to provide pads and tampons, but that the students are failing to take responsibility for themselves, because they are less well informed and responsible than they should be. This is not the schools' fault, it is the fault of the students and their parents. Schools can pr

Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well as with many others, the problem is not that the schools are failing to provide pads and tampons, but that the students are failing to take responsibility for themselves, because they are less well informed and responsible than they should be. This is not the schools' fault, it is the fault of the students and their parents. Schools can provide tampons or pa

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well as with many others, the problem is not that the schools are failing to provide pads and tampons, but that the students are failing to take responsibility for themselves, because they are less well informed and responsible than they should be. This is not the schools' fault, it is the fault of the students and their parents. Schools can provide tampons or pads in case of emerge

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well as with many others, the problem is not that the schools are failing to provide pads and tampons, but that the students are failing to take responsibility for themselves, because they are less well informed and responsible than they should be. This is not the schools' fault, it is the fault of the students and their parents. Schools can provide tampons or pads in case of emergencies, but they can

Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well as with many others, the problem is not that the schools are failing to provide pads and tampons, but that the students are failing to take responsibility for themselves, because they are less well informed and responsible than they should be. This is not the schools' fault, it is the fault of the students and their parents. Schools can provide tampons or pads in case of emergencies, but they can't fix irresponsi

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well as with many others, the problem is not that the schools are failing to provide pads and tampons, but that the students are failing to take responsibility for themselves, because they are less well informed and responsible than they should be. This is not the schools' fault, it is the fault of the students and their parents. Schools can provide tampons or pads in case of emergencies, but they can't fix irresponsibility and lack of b

Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well as with many others, the problem is not that the schools are failing to provide pads and tampons, but that the students are failing to take responsibility for themselves, because they are less well informed and responsible than they should be. This is not the schools' fault, it is the fault of the students and their parents. Schools can provide tampons or pads in case of emergencies, but they can't fix irresponsibility and lack of basic knowledge

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well as with many others, the problem is not that the schools are failing to provide pads and tampons, but that the students are failing to take responsibility for themselves, because they are less well informed and responsible than they should be. This is not the schools' fault, it is the fault of the students and their parents. Schools can provide tampons or pads in case of emergencies, but they can't fix irresponsibility and lack of basic knowledge, that responsibil

Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well as with many others, the problem is not that the schools are failing to provide pads and tampons, but that the students are failing to take responsibility for themselves, because they are less well informed and responsible than they should be. This is not the schools' fault, it is the fault of the students and their parents. Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this 'debate' smacks of political correctness and posturing, rather than a real concern for the welfare of female students. Being male, of course I don't know what it's like to have a period, and I have never experienced period shaming, but I do know what it's like to be a teenager, and I went to school with plenty of girls who were having their periods for the first time. In my experience, "period poverty" was not a problem. Girls would occasionally have an "accident" and students would make fun of them, but junior high school students are cruel, and they make fun of everyone, for a variety of reasons.  Girls tended to be hyper-sensitive about the possibility of being mocked for having an accident, and I assume that they would carry around extra pads and tampons in case of emergency. So, the situation was mostly taken care of, by the girls themselves, and their families, or helpful peers.

I did not attend a private school, or a school in a wealthy area with exclusively wealthy students, in fact there were many low income students there, and they were able to handle this. Is it possible that in schools now,  the situation is different? I'm puzzled to explain why this would be. Are students poorer now? Are they more likely to be mocked by increasingly cruel peers? Are young women now more likely to be uniformed about their periods? Or are they just less responsible and less capable of taking care of themselves?

I suspect in this case, as well as with many others, the problem is not that the schools are failing to provide pads and tampons, but that the students are failing to take responsibility for themselves, because they are less well informed and responsible than they should be. This is not the schools' fault, it is the fault of the students and their parents. Schools can provide tampons or pads in case of emergencies, but they can't fix irresponsibility and lack of basic knowledge, that responsibility lies with these girls' families, and with the girls themselves.
